results.title: New Zealand's exotic forests
results.creator_credit: Margaret Thomson, Stanhope Andrews and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Man-made pine forests are the main timber resources of New Zealand. At Kaingarva, the largest such forest in the world, the Dominion has sufficient supplies for the next few centuries. The film explains that the abundance of natural forests in early days provided a seemingly inexhaustible supply of timber, resulting in the deforestation of large areas. Today (1949), in spite of the development of new forests, timber resources are being used to the better advantage.

results.title: New york: the wonder city
results.brief_description: Presents glimpses of the following highlights in New York City: views of New York harbour; Ellis Island; Statue of Liberty; Broadway; Wall Street; Stock Echange; City Hall; The Tombs (Prison); Brooklyn Bridge; the Bowery; Chinatown; Festivities; Washington Square; Fifth Avenue; Greenwich Village; Great pier on the Hudson, liners; Flat Iron building; Church of Transfiguration; Pennsylvania Station; Empire State building; Chrysler building; Public Library; Park Avenue; St Patrick’s Cathedral; Rockefeller Centre; dance rehearsals on the rooftop of Radio City Music Hall; Central Park activities; Metropolitan Museum of Art; Museum of Natural History; Columbia University; Riverside Drive; tomb of General Grant; children dancing in the streets of Harlem; George Washington Bridge. The film closes with footage of the city’s night lights. Edited by Eugene W. Castle.

results.title: New York University: physical rehabilitation
results.creator_credit: Al Wasserman, Irving Gitlin and CBS Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Search”.
Shows how a paraplegic war veteran learns again to stand, walk, climb stairs, sit in a wheel chair and finally achieve a symbolic goal; getting a cup of water from a cooler by himself. Shows this veteran as the focal point of many new skills and techniques.

results.title: New worlds for old
results.creator_credit: Maslyn Williams and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A survey of the progress being made in Papua and New Guinea, showing new industries, new roads and means of transport, the introduction of sheep, cattle and goats, and the way in which the natives are being encouraged to cooperate in these activities.

results.title: New ways with wool
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson, Les Davidson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The production of many new types of synthetic fibres is a threat to the future of the Australian wool industry - the chemist is producing new materials more closely resembling the characteristics of wool. This film, showing how the wool industry is meeting this challenge, is an account of the work being done at various research centres throughout the Commonwealth, investigating and improving the production, processing, and use of wool.

results.title: New universities
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Look at Life”.
A survey of the new universities program which seeks to extend facilities for university training in England. Taking the University of Sussex as the principal example, the film gives a picture of student life and activities in the fine modern buildings designed by Sir Basil Spence.

results.title: New town
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
Commonwealth Teleview Series - Visiting Harlow, a British satellite town, Christopher Chataway discusses this ‘modern’ building phenomenon with Frederick Gibberd, the city’s architect-planner. Chataway also interviews people living and working in the town, obtaining their views on this experiment in town planning.

results.title: New town
results.creator_credit: John Halas, Joy Batchelor and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: A cartoon film explaining the need for town planning to avoid a repetition of past mistakes. Diagrams illustrate how towns have grown without provision being made for proper transport, for the separation of industrial and residential areas and the provision of playgrounds and conveniently situated shopping centres.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Halas, Joy Batchelor and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
